It‚Äôs hard to believe that Fall 2023 marks the beginning of my tenth year at Winona State! I continue to love working in the Mathematics and Statistics department. Our students continue to invigorate and inspire me. My colleagues continue to be the best in the business ‚Äì intelligent, collaborative, and innovative, with a deep care for the learning experience of the students we serve. It‚Äôs been a wonderful ten years, and every day I am grateful to be a part of the Winona State community. Here‚Äôs to the next ten, and the ten beyond that!
My narrative details my activities of the past five years as Associate professor, January 2019 ‚Äì December 2023. I would weight my efforts in the five criteria during this time span accordingly:
Criterion 1: Teaching effectiveness; 40% Criterion 2: Scholarship and creative achievement; 30% Criterion 3: Continuing preparation; 5% Criterion 4: Student growth and development; 10% Criterion 5: Service to the university and community; 15%

I was awarded funding by the American Eagle Foundation to analyze bald eagle telemetry data during sabbatical. Based on this work I published two papers in peer-reviewed journals and presented at national conferences. Back to top
I was very grateful to receive a sabbatical during the academic year 2020-21. I enjoyed the break from teaching and the chance to engage in some very interesting applied research with excellent collaborators from around the country. My primary sabbatical research project was a major collaboration with Dr. Tricia Miller, Dr. Adam Duerr, and Missy Braham of Conservation Science Global; and Dr. Todd Katzner and Manuela Huso of U.S. Geological Survey. Over the last several years my collaborators had collected a large data set containing millions of GPS locations from 79 Bald Eagles, 30 free-flying birds captured in winter, 5 from rehabilitation facilities, and 44 tagged as nestlings. The resulting data are measured on very short intervals, as little as every 5 seconds, resulting in millions of geospatial and biological measurements. The below photos shows the same 7-week old bald eagle from above, after the telemetry device was attached and a close-up of the device.
The richness and extent of the data collected by these devices call for an automated process to classify and interpret the animal movement data. A defining feature of many previous methods developed for interpreting animal movement is that they were initially¬†illustrated with telemetry data collected at relatively long time intervals. My role in this research was to apply statistical methods to that could be used to automate classifying risk to eagles from wind turbines using short-interval GPS telemetry data. To support my research efforts during sabbatical, Dr. Miller and I submitted a grant proposal to the American Eagle Foundation for $19,950.27. This was primarily to make up some of the income lost due to taking a sabbatical for an entire year. The grant was fully awarded.
Grant application packet
Grant award
The first part of my sabbatical research involved applying a framework for using K-means clustering to classify bird behavior using points from short time interval GPS tracks. My efforts on this part of the research resulted in an article on which I am first-author in Ecology and Evolution.
Bergen, S.,¬†Huso, M. M.,¬†Duerr, A. E.,¬†Braham, M. A.,¬†Katzner, T. E.,¬†Schmuecker, S., &¬†Miller, T. A.¬†(2022).¬†Classifying behavior from short-interval biologging data: An example with GPS tracking of birds.¬†Ecology and Evolution,¬†12, e08395.¬†https://doi.org/10.1002/ece3.8395 The next step in my work involved classifying behavior using environmental features. The behaviors we were interested in classifying corresponded to different levels of risk from wind turbines. To carry out the classification I used boosted classification trees (BCTs) as implemented in the open source XGBoost package. XGBoost is a ‚Äúbig data‚Äù analysis tool that is computationally feasible even with billions of data observations, affording users a scalable and efficient implementation of BCTs with dramatic implications for model training. In this part of my research I applied BCT modeling with XGBoost to predict three categories of risk of bald eagle colliding with wind turbines in Iowa, and compared its predictive performance and computational time to other supervised learning methods.
I am the lead author on a second article summarizing this work in the highly-touted Methods in Ecology and Evolution.
Bergen, S.,¬†Huso, M. M.,¬†Duerr, A. E.,¬†Braham, M. A.,¬†Schmuecker, S.,¬†Miller, T. A., &¬†Katzner, T. E.¬†(2023).¬†A review of supervised learning methods for classifying animal behavioural states from environmental features.¬†Methods in Ecology and Evolution,¬†14,¬†189‚Äì202.¬†https://doi.org/10.1111/2041-210X.14019 In addition the manuscripts, we submitted an abstract to the 2020 Wind Wildlife Research Meeting (that was held virtually Dec 1-4, 2020), which was accepted. This presentation centered mostly on the first part of my research, using K-means to cluster bald eagle flight. A video of the presentation is available by following the URL linked in the ‚Ä¶

During Fall 2020 I sat in on Dr. Todd Iverson‚Äôs course DSCI 330: Management of Unstructured Data. Below is a screenshot of one of my ‚Äúhomework‚Äù assignments:
I took the WeTeach course for effective online course design. Back to top
I have taught online multiple times and wanted to learn more about effective online course design, especially given the growth of online teaching especially amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. To that end I completed the WeTeach course for effective online/blended course design and delivery in Summer 2020.
One of the best takeaways from this class for me was to create a discussion board for students to introduce themselves at the beginning of the semester. I have done this in all my online offerings since taking WeTeach. I think students appreciate this chance to get to know one another, as it helps reduce the isolation that can be an issue in online courses. It also gives students a way to find people to work with in homework groups if they do not already know someone in the course.
I read several books and online resources on data visualization design and best practices. Back to top
I have explored many resources in preparation for teaching DSCI 310: Data visualization. As described in Criterion 1, I wanted to remake the way I taught DSCI 310 by focusing more on the concepts of quality data visualization. This included expanding my treatment of visual perception and designing for aesthetics and accessibility. The following books and online resources have proved hugely instrumental to my course design and thinking on data visualization in general and DSCI 310 specifically:
Show me the Numbers by Stephen Few
Storytelling with Data by Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic
Storytelling with Data: Let‚Äôs practice! By Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic
The Truthful Art by Alberto Cairo
The Grammar of Graphics by Leland Wilkinson
#MakeoverMonday by Andy Kriebel and Eva Murray
I sought out professional data visualizations as inspiration for DSCI 310 assignments. Back to top
One way students improve as data visualizers is working to visualize a data set, then seeing a very high quality visual perspective on the same data. To that end, most of the design tasks I set my students in the data visualization course have a published visualization as its inspiration, which I show students after they have submitted their final drafts. Some examples are below.

I developed high-quality activities and projects for DSCI 210: Data Science Back to top
I taught DSCI 210 for my first time in Fall 2019 and Spring 2020. I inherited a quality curriculum outline with solid content from my colleague Dr. Todd Iverson. One area where I saw room for improvement was with in-class activities and class projects.
Activities Building upon Dr. Iverson‚Äôs content, I developed a suite of near-daily activities to illustrate many of the concepts he had brought into the course. Many of these activities drew from data brought to the Statistical Consulting Center, which I had been directing for a couple years. Here are some examples.
Activity Example 1: WSU vehicle requests The screenshot below shows data on requests for WSU vehicles:
{width=‚Äú6.5in‚Äù height=‚Äú3.0868055555555554in‚Äù}
Some of the tasks students had to do:
Clean ‚ÄúDestination City,‚Äù which was very messy as requesting parties could just type in their destination resulting in many variants of the same place (e.g. St. Paul; St paul; st paul; ST Paul St Paul/MPLS).
Pull off number of passengers, which is embedded in the Vehicle(s) field.
Compute average trip length for each vehicle, which requires differencing Departure from Return.
Find number of vehicles used for each trip, which required splitting the Vehicle(s) column when it contained multiple vehicles.
Activity Example 2: trout spawning data The data below came from a consulting client, measuring redds (spawning nests) of stream trout.
From a data science perspective, there are many issues with this data that students had to grapple with including:
Highlighting indicating grouping status;
Different sections of streams contained in different spreadsheets;
Bold lines indicating 1000-yard segments;
One separate Excel file for each of 4 different years.
Activity Example 3: rape myth agreement This data set also came from a consulting client working on a counsellor‚Äôs education master‚Äôs thesis. She wanted to compare rape myth belief as measured by the Illinois Rape Myth Acceptance Scale before and after a training on gender-based violence among student athletes. The raw data and the clean data are shown below:
Students needed to recode all of the Likert-scale items to come up with a single score for each student, then match the scores on the pre- and post-training data to develop the clean data set on the right.
Projects Along with the in-class activities, I developed several in-class projects that required substantial application of the DSCI 210 content.
Project example 1: COVID-19 trends This project required students to pull data from a Github repository, clean it, and visualize it. This was a final project which required a substantial amount of coding, cleaning, and visualizing with R:
Project example 2: MUDAC 2020 This final project build on MUDAC 2020, which focused on understanding whether various motions made during civil rights trials could predict the outcome of the trial. Some of the questions students had to answer with this data involved whether filing rates differed by district, and how the prevalence and frequency of motions impacted likelihood of cases being settled or taken to trial. Students had to use association rules, a recently learned technique, to analyze the former.
Feedback Student feedback on the activities and project was very positive. Below are student responses to the statement ‚ÄúThe in-class activities helped me to understand the course material,‚Äù combined across both Fall 2019 and Spring 2020 semesters:

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}} Press Space to play!
One Two Three A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation

Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view Themes black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}} Custom CSS Example Let‚Äôs make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; } Questions? Ask
